item.title: Sharing some thoughts from a conference organizer
item.description:
Note: this blog post is currently in a draft state. Do not trust its actual content. See you soon for a more definitive content.


Chilling moment during #PTS22
photo by doegox under CC BY-NC-SA

2022 has been quite a crucial year in the Pass the SALT conference short history. We had to switch back to an in person form of event.

It can seem quite obvious, but after two years of full remote conference, it has been quite challenging.

As often said, #SharingIsCaring!

So, in this blogpost, I will share:

  • some doubts I have crossed during the restart of the conference
  • some thoughts about conference organization after 15 years of involvement as a volunteer conference founder and organiser.

Being back on stage after 2 years long pandemic

When you have organized an event once a year for more than 10 years and suddenly, pandemic stops you and your friends during more than 2 years, it impacts you. No more physical contact nor social interaction whereas a conference is essentially a face-to-face event. Even if you don‚Äôt see or admit it, it hurts you as a social person!

After that, the relaunch of the event hasn‚Äôt be a easy path. One month before the #PTS22 event, I have even decided to resign just after the 2022 edition. I have shared it with @doegox and @_cryptocorn_.

Why resigning?

I didn‚Äôt see the point of investing time and energy in events like Pass the SALT anymore.

I doubted my own added value. I also doubted the impact that this type of event could have on the security ecosystem, on the speakers and on the attendees.

I have been quite frustated all along the process of restarting the event under its in person form:

  • less attendees have registered and finally came ,
  • we had to deal with constraints due to the pandemic (ex.: how to find a ‚Äúsafe‚Äù location for the social event?).
  • less speakers were also eager to physically attend the conference. I definitively understand their point of view. But it has been very frustrating on my side because meeting new speakers, make interactions happen between them and other speakers or attendees is at the core of the event.

Failing to provoke desire into some potential speakers heart has been really hard to live during this fragile moment of relaunching the event. I wasn‚Äôt sure anymore to have the words and the vision to lead this conference and convince people to participate.

Finally, @doegox convinced me to postpone my announcement after the event. Social interactions during the event have generated enough energy to do the magic! For the moment at least ¬Ø_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

And now, some thoughts about organizing conferences!

For the record, my experience as a conference organizer comes from:

  • RMLL Security track curator role from 2008 to 2017
  • and Pass the SALT founder and organizer since 2018.

One more conference, really?

Despite a small adjustement after the pandemic period and some conferences stop, we can say that IT or Security conferences are just everywhere nowadays.

From local events run by volunteers to huge commercial events in the middle of the desert. Specialized on a particular topic or covering all the modern Security landscape. Not being able to find the right one for you is quite difficult, aside the location and the cost.

I think that your main challenge before launching a new conference is to find a brand new angle, not already covered by another conference, at least in your area.

Of course, you can run an event locally without any specific topic/angle aside Security. A lot of BSides events are like that. Your event will provide to the local community the opportunity to encounter seasoned speakers and do social networking. It will have an impact, no problem wih that.

Your mission, both a tool and a responsibility

But, not having a specific focus or mission will be a lack on the long term. The event will have a harder time providing a clear vision of what it will have brought to the community.

Having a specific mission provides you your identity.

First, having your own mission is a big part of your attractivity. For potential speakers, for attendees, for the community.

Then, if you respect your mission at each step of your decision process, your mission becomes an effective tool to maintain consistency over the long term.

Being consistent over time with your mission helps you build credibility for your event and allows you to build trust with participants and the broader security community.

Apology of long term actions

After speaking about your identity, let‚Äôs give a look to the footprint you might leave into the community history.

My preferred way to think and act is to do things on the long time scale. Because it forces you to be humble and to build things in a solid way (try to).

Acting on the long term have some positive impacts on conference organizing:

  • organizers less suffer from the instantaneous results quest that modern world is asking them for ,
  • organizers are pushed to adopt an iterative rythm
  • these iterations secure the foundation upon your event is built on and grows.

To illustrate, Pass the SALT is dedicated to Free Software and Security.

The values that underpin the event are:

  • transparency,
  • freedom of access
  • and collaboration between individuals.

In our case, being part of the long term and act in line with our mission therefore translates into multiple choices:

  • set up an event whose access is free of charge for all (talks, workshops, pauses and social event included);
    ‚û°Ô∏è done since 2008 ;
  • adding each year to a self hosted archive site all the slides and videos produced during the current edition ;
    ‚û°Ô∏è done since 2008 ;
  • document into the open all collaborations resulting from the conference.
    ‚û°Ô∏è done since 2011.

Standing on the shoulders of giants

But long term actions came also from our history.


full rom before attending Lunar talk about Tor during RMLL 2014
photo by doegox under CC BY-NC-SA

Our roots mainly come from the Libre Software Meeting (or Rencontres Mondiales du Logiciel Libre / RMLL in French).

Apart from RMLL, Philippe has been part of the BruCon for years or helped at Hack.lu. On his side, Mathieu has been a member of the SSTIC org team for a long time.

We have all being part of the RMLL organization, mainly as Security track curators. We have learned a lot from this organization team, from the achievements and maybe even more from the fails!

For example, we learned that changing almost all the organization team as done each year by RMLL since 2003 is a sure win for loosing expertise and deep understanding of how an event works.

So, since we founded Pass the SALT, we paid a special attention to:

  • the management of our small team,
  • document the functioning of the conference for new members or simply to be able to capitalize a little more year after year.

Being part of a bigger event than our small track also helped us to safely learn the job and try some ideas: setting up an English only spoken track, see the benefits of having a speakers dinner etc.

Hats off to the creators of RMLL and core team members from 2008 to 2017! Learned a lot and Pass the SALT wouldn‚Äôt be there without you üëè

Special attention: this year, we have the surprise to see one of RMLL colleagues, Georges Khaznadar, former Education track co curator, to be in the room at #PTS22. A very emotional moment for me and I am really sad not having been able to share a longer moment with you, Georges! I hope during a next edition ‚ù§Ô∏èü§û

A little extra soul

As a small event, we can not rely on the fact we would be a must-attend event. We have to prove that this event is a little special and deserves to visit it!

We created our conference with a special care to the details and as users of our own work.


building a new feature: adding a foldable program to #PTS22 badge
photo by doegox under CC BY-NC-SA license

For example, we try to:

  • make access to the conference as easy as possible for both attendees and speakers (no cost entry, no personal information collection, straight forward registration process or detailed information on website and pushed to particpants mailbox) ;
  • even if it is a zero cost event, set up paid pauses and social event to maximize exchange times ;
  • put a special attention to the (always documented!) badge design production ;
  • provide a yearly report with all the figures and the detailed feedback received from speakers and attendees.

We also always try to go to people, speak with a lot of present people, putting as much affect as we can into these exchanges!


Sharing moments during #PTS22 speakers dinner
photo by doegox under CC BY-NC-SA license

This last part is quite important for me. We all organize this event to encounter people, new ones and old friends. For my part, without meetings, I would just quit the boat, as simple as that.

One of our attendees, past speaker and seasonned conference organizer qualifies us as an event with ‚Äúa little extra soul‚Äù ü§©

Thanks a lot @tomchop_, we will try not to disappoint you in the future üòò

Summer

Due to our history (RMLL we are looking at you!), our conference has always been held during the first days of July.

I use to run the conference organization with my friends and then, I usually disappear (almost) for 2 or 3 weeks somewhere right after.


Calm and reloading in the middle of nowhere
photo by /me under CC BY-NC-SA license

It is a way to come down softly after the rush of emotions generated by the conference and its participants.

If you have participated to that kind of events as an organizer or even an attendee, it may be like going to an intense festival. It takes time to digest all the emotions and ideas you have felt or crossed during these few days.

This after-event period is a very profitable moment for me to try to transform all these emotions and ideas into new directions for the next iteration of the conference.


Sat in front of Red Lines installation by Evan Roth, Rencontres d‚Äôarles 2022
photo by F.B.(c)

Summer is also the period of Music, Photography festivals. I always try to participate to these kind of events. I try also to find and read interviews of festival organizers. For example, give a try to this Sam Stourdz√© interview [fr], former Rencontres d‚ÄôArles director (main FR ). It is such a rich source of inspiration despite the differences between the events.

All of this also provides you a lot of new perspectives and ideas you can try to adapt to your own event to improve it üôÇ.

I finally came to the end of this quite (too?) long article. I hope you enjoy the ride and of course, feel free to come back to me to exchange about these topics.

Quand la vie bascule

Ce dernier le renvoie apr√®s un premier diagnostic en soins intensifs √† l‚Äôh√¥pital Saint Andr√© de Bordeaux.

Diagnostic consolid√© : une maladie auto-immune foudroie notre proche. Apr√®s une premi√®re explication d‚Äôune doctoresse, la gravit√© de la situation nous saisit.

Vont se succ√©der alors 8 semaines de r√©animation avec une forme atypique et tr√®s douloureuse de sa maladie, des comas provoqu√©s pour ‚Äúg√©rer‚Äù ses douleurs insoutenables, une perte d‚Äôautonomie et de communication quasi totale et un pronostic de r√©cup√©ration des plus incertains.

L‚Äôenfer est l√†, pr√©sent et constant. Pour le patient. Pour nous. Pour l‚Äô√©quipe.

Pouvoir venir voir notre proche en r√©animation.

Nous avons pu voir quotidiennement notre proche en r√©animation. Une personne par jour. Nous avons alterner, un jour sur deux. Et ce malgr√© la pr√©sence de patients COVID occupant la quasi totalit√© des chambres du service.

Un premier remerciement √† l‚Äô√©quipe de s‚Äô√™tre organis√©e ainsi car on n‚Äôose pas imaginer comment notre proche aurait pu (sur)vivre (√†) sa maladie coup√© de sa famille alors que d√©j√†, sa maladie l‚Äô√©touffait et le privait de tout lien avec l‚Äôext√©rieur. Cela a compt√©. Vraiment.

R√©action d‚Äô√©quipe, avec humilit√© et pers√©v√©rance.

Le caract√®re atypique de sa maladie a fait que les traitements d√©cid√©s par l‚Äô√©quipe m√©dicale n‚Äôont pas toujours r√©pondu comme attendu.

Notre proche a souffert de douleurs insoutenables qui ont oblig√© les docteurs √† le plonger plusieurs fois en s√©dation profonde.

L‚Äô√©quipe a dout√©, a rechalleng√© ses diagnostics.

Et pourtant, jamais nous n‚Äôavons eu le sentiment que l‚Äô√©quipe se d√©sagr√©geait, que des indivualit√©s se d√©solidarisaient du reste des professionnels qui nous entouraient.

A chaque fois, les docteurs, quels qu‚Äôils soient, nous ont r√©pondu de mani√®re factuelle, avec des explications sur o√π ils voulaient aller, pourquoi ils y allaient.

De m√™me, quand ils ne savaient pas ce qui se passait, qu‚Äôun traitement ne donnait pas les r√©sultats attendus, qu‚Äôun acte ne se passait pas comme pr√©vu, l‚Äô√©quipe m√©dicale nous le disait en toute transparence, avec humilit√© mais aussi avec pers√©v√©rance.

Tout cela permet en tant que patient (ou proches de patients) de donner sa confiance √† l‚Äô√©quipe et de sentir que l‚Äôon est toujours traiter comme une personne humaine ayant son int√©grit√© et non comme un cas. Cela peut paraitre √©vident mais cela fait une diff√©rence √©norme. Vraiment.

Une humanit√©, une implication et une transparence rare.

Le fait de pouvoir passer plusieurs heures par jour, 7 jours sur 7, pendant plusieurs semaines, aupr√®s de son proche malade fait que nous sommes immerg√©s dans la vie du service. C‚Äôest une vraie avanc√©e pour les familles qui font partie de la vie du service et ne sont plus des √©l√©ments p√©riph√©riques, de passage.

Il faut, je pense, pour tol√©rer cela en tant qu‚Äô√©quipe soignante une grande confiance en soi et une vraie volont√© de transparence. Bravo, vraiment, car cela change tout.

Nous avons pu voir comment toute l‚Äô√©quipe (docteurs, aides-soignant.e.s, infirmier.e.s, kin√©s, psychologues, socio-esth√©ticiennes, personnel de m√©nage) faisait preuve d‚Äôune humanit√© constante dans leur comportement vis √† vis des patients. Cela permet au patient de garder sa dignit√© malgr√© les moments de grande d√©tresse et de grande vuln√©rabilit√© qu‚Äôil traverse.

De m√™me, dans les moments difficiles, la totalit√© du personnel √©tait concern√©, affect√©, √† l‚Äôunisson de notre v√©cu. Le tout en mettant le traitement de la douleur au coeur de leurs pr√©occupations de soignants.

Dans les pratiques m√©dicales de l‚Äô√©quipe, le patient est vraiment au coeur du sujet.

Par exemple, lors des mises en s√©dation profonde, un cahier de suivi √©tait mis √† disposition afin de raconter jour par jour ce que le patient s√©dat√© vivait, ce qui se passait autour de lui. Les soignants faisaient l‚Äôeffort de le remplir quotidiennement tout autant que nous, sa famille. Au r√©veil du patient, ce cahier devient un outil de reconstruction qui lui permet d‚Äôobjectiver ses ‚Äúsouvenirs‚Äù, ses cauchemars etc.

Un accompagnement tellement utile.

En parrall√®le du soin pur de la maladie, des personnels interviennent aupr√®s du patient et de ses proches comme la psychologue qui travaille de mani√®re agile, mettant √† profit toutes les opportunit√©s pour faire parler, mettre des mots et donner des cl√©s pour g√©rer ces moments si douloureux et traumatisants.

De m√™me, une socio esth√©ticienne passe aupr√®s des patients et son intervention est d‚Äôune aide r√©elle pour le maintien du bien √™tre et de l‚Äôimage de soi du patient.

Merci aussi pour tout cela.

Merci.

Un √©norme et sinc√®re merci, donc, √† tous les membres de l‚Äô√©quipe de l‚Äôunit√© de r√©animation et de soins intensifs de l‚Äôh√¥pital Saint Andr√© pour votre mani√®re de fonctionner, votre implication, votre humanit√©.

Un dernier d√©tail qui n‚Äôen est peut-√™tre pas un : au moment de quitter votre service, o√π nous avions pourtant travers√© tellement de moments douloureux, nous avons √©t√© saisi d‚Äôun bref moment de crainte, de ne pas vouloir quitter le service. Significatif.

Post scriptum : ce parcours de soin s‚Äôest op√©r√© au sein de l‚Äôh√¥pital public et aucune avance de frais ne nous a √©t√© demand√© ni avant, ni apr√®s les soins. Traverser une telle √©preuve sans avoir, en plus, √† se mobiliser pour payer les soins est une vraie aide tant pour les familles que pour la r√©ussite des soins. Ce fut en effet autant d‚Äô√©nergie que nous avons pu investir dans l‚Äôaccompagnement de notre proche.

Cela est rendu possible gr√¢ce au fonctionnement actuel de notre syst√®me d‚ÄôAssurance Maladie : ‚ÄúOn contribue √† hauteur de ses possiblit√©s, on re√ßoit √† hauteur de ses besoins.‚Äù.

La seule le√ßon que nous voulons partager ici : n‚Äôoublions jamais la valeur de ce syst√®me, battons nous √† chaque fois qu‚Äôil est attaqu√© tant sur son financement que sur le versant hospitalier.

item.title: RMLL Security track - why, how and for which results
item.description:
JC Jones during RMLL Sec 2016 - photo by Eric Leblond under CC BY-NC-SA

RMLL Security track : why, how and for which results

Note: after the lost of the original blogpost from 2017, I have restored an original version that I have updated with additions from late 2019.

After many years of curation of the Security Track of the RMLL (a French generalist multi tracks conference about Free Software), we have decided to create in 2018 a free (as in free beer) event dedicated to Security and Free Software: Pass the SALT, Security And Libre Talks.

For my part, I have started to curate the security track (and adminsys in early years) in 2008 at Mont de Marsan :)

We have decided to do it because as a technical track, we no more felt ‚Äúat home‚Äù in a conference that went more year after year toward a artistic, political and communities direction. This direction was very interesting for the RMLL but too far from our core topic to feel comfortable enough as track curators but also for the event organizers.

We are convinced of the value that Free Software provides to all of us, citizens of the world, in the Security area. And having a conference dedicated to it is a way for us to contribute to its expansion.

On this page, we will expose our goals for this new conference and the way we want to follow to reach them.

Our goals for Pass the SALT

Discussion between Fran√ßois Marier, Eric Leblond and Werner Koch during 2013 RMLL Security Track in Brussels - photo CC BY-NC-SA by P. Teuwen

To understand the objectives and the spirit, Peter Czanik, lecturer, gave us some answers in the report of his participation in the RMLL 2017.

Here is how he summarized his coming at the 2017 RMLL Security track:

‚ÄúI participated again in Security track ‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúParticipated‚Äù as I did not only give a talk on syslog-ng there, but also sat in to most of the presentations and had very good discussions both with visitors and fellow speakers. The organizers brought together talks from diverse IT security-related fields, a very good opportunity for cross-pollination of ideas.‚Äù

Note: emphasis is on our own.

Peter has perfectly synthesized what we are trying to achieve through the RMLL Security track year after year:

Do our best to facilitate meetings and exchanges between lecturers and the public. The goal is that these exchanges generate collaborations between developers or projects but also produce new features in free software of the Security sphere.

And it is what we will want to achieve year after year with Pass the SALT.

How to reach our goals

Here, we are not going to give a detailed list of things we think that have to be done but rather, a short list of important (according to us) levers that helped us reaching these goals.

1> Cost: a free access event

First of all, we want to provide a free event to attendees. According to us, this is the best way to enable all kind of attendees to come : we think about students or people with low income but it is also a way to see professionals coming on their own without having to negociate money with their company.

2> Content: a security & free software event with most of the security topics covered

While respecting the technical and free software DNA of the conference, we try to ensure that as many security disciplines as possible are represented in the topics covered by the talks and workshops.

During the first 2 Pass the SALT editions, we managed to offer many different sessions with among other topics: low level security, offensive security, secure programming, security at scale, privacy or network security.

We want both attendees and speakers to confront to different disciplines and topics of Security that are not always familiar to them. This allows everyone to discover new fields of exploration and to pick innovative solutions that she/he can reuse in her/his projects or work.

3> For attendees: an open minded and accessible atmosphere

Beyond the different and varied subjects, we also try to establish a climate as friendly as possible in order to maximize exchanges. During the conference, it is very rare to find a ‚Äústar attitude‚Äù among our speakers. They are all free software users and/or developers and so, perfectly understand the importance of sharing with and helping people. So, we set up:

  • pauses: during which, we do our best to encourage attendees to interact with speakers,
  • social event: organization provides some (usually 2) free drinks and tries to encourage one more time exchanges between people :)

4> For speakers: a comfortable and caring event

It is also very important for us that the speakers feel comfortable for coming and attending : they usually don‚Äôt know the event (and so its attendees), the city and even sometimes the country. So we provide:

  • a dedicated communication channel: on a private mailing list we provide complete information (how to come, to find accommodations, to do their talk, to contact us, to be reimbursed etc.),
  • full contact list and fast feedback loop: in order to be able to get in touch and have answers quickly from the org team,
  • speakers dinner: during the event, we also set up a speakers‚Äô dinner. The goal is to provide them yet another opportunity to get to know each other better, exchange and let ideas ‚Äúpollinate‚Äù :-)

The goal is for all lecturers to come in confidence, get rid of most of their practical questions to be able to take advantage of the event in the most open way.

And for which result?

But so, for real, have you got any results to share? Yes we have! Just give a look to our achievements page :-)

item.title: My first Unix session was a password hijack experience
item.description:
VT220 terminal - Photo under Public Domain license by Shansov.net / Wikimedia

I discovered Unix (not Linux) at college in Bordeaux, in 1989. After a first course about Unix and its concepts, our professor gave us our credentials to be able to login on our school Unix system.

This computer was a HP 9000 server running a Unix OS. The ‚Äúmachine room‚Äù was in fact divided in two rooms. The first one was the ‚Äúwhite room‚Äù, a restricted access area with only the big box inside aka the main server : 1,5m high and several meters long. The second room was the room dedicated to the twenty passive terminals (VT100/VT220 emulation maybe) used to login on the Unix system.

So, with my user account and password, I sat in front of one of the terminals. I entered my user account and my password. Failed. I just thinked that I mispelled one of them, I retried and I managed to log in. The rest of the session was successful : I was able to try the few commands I learned during my first lesson.

But. The day after, I was not able to log in anymore. 2nd year students were just laughing in the terminals room. I asked why. They stopped laughing, picked a terminal and introduced me to the .logout functionnality. It is used to execute a set of commands when you leave your current session. They have customized their own .logout script in order to display a screen almost identical to the normal login screen.

Yes, you see? My first try to enter my credentials the day before was done on a faked login screen ;-) The student who was connected before me got my credentials and just has to change my password. After getting my credentials, the commands executed by the .logout script ended and the student session also. So I retried to enter my credentials in front of the real login screen.

It was in 1989. On a Unix system. Connected to ‚Ä¶ nothing : no network available at this time on this server. And password theft was already a game :-)

Je voulais vous faire un petit retour sur un moment que j‚Äôai v√©cu l‚Äôan pass√© avec ma fille cadette. Contrairement √† l‚Äôain√©e, elle n‚Äôavait jamais eu envie d‚Äôaller sur Internet et je me disais que son apprentissage allait √™tre plus laborieux que pour sa s≈ìur.

L‚Äôan pass√©, ma fille de 10 ans, en CM2, a donc d√©couvert le web.

L√†, son instit lui avait demand√© d‚Äôeffectuer une recherche sur Rapha√´l, le peintre italien.

Du coup, on d√©marre sous son profil sur Ubuntu. Je lui explique les bases d‚Äôun navigateur web (Firefox inside ;) ) : la zone d‚Äôadresse, la zone de recherche, les moteurs de recherches enregistr√©s.

‚ÄúOn peut rajouter des moteurs de recherches ? Trop classe !‚Äù Je souris ;-)

Puis explication des liens hypertextes, changement de pages, puis explication de Wikipedia, son fonctionnement, ses limites :

‚ÄúWikipedia est √©crit par des gens comme toi et moi. Ils peuvent faire des erreurs. Il faut croiser ses sources (dico, magazines etc)‚Äù

Mais je sentais bien que je la barbais un peu.

Au bout de 10 minutes, devinez quoi ?

Elle : ‚ÄúPapa, l√†, je crois qu‚Äôils se sont tromp√©s sur Wikip√©dia !‚Äù
Moi (dubitatif) : ‚ÄúTu es s√ªre, ma puce ?‚Äù
Elle : ‚ÄúOui, oui. Ce n‚Äôest pas de Rapha√´l, la tapisserie de la Dame √† la Licorne. Ils ont confondu avec le tableau du m√™me nom.‚Äù
Moi : ‚ÄúS√©rieux ?‚Äù
Elle (me coupant) : ‚ÄúTiens, regarde, ils en reparlent un peu plus loin sur la page. Et l√†, le lien va bien sur le tableau !‚Äù

Elle avait raison ! j‚Äô√©tais scotch√©.

On avait vu il y a 2 ans la tapisserie de la Dame √† la Licorne √† Cluny (Paris). Elle s‚Äôen est servi pour d√©tecter l‚Äôerreur et trouver le bon lien un peu plus loin dans la page.

J‚Äô√©tais vraiment content qu‚Äôelle ait pu voir par elle m√™me que :

  • ce qu‚Äôelle lit sur Internet doit √™tre v√©rifi√©

item.title: RMLL/LSM 2010 - 2/3 - Internationalization
item.description:
This post is part of 3 posts about 2010 LSM debriefing. The 3 topics covered will be :

  • Topics and sharing a same vision (fr)
  • internationalization (this post)
  • RMLL : perfect setup (fr)

Disclamer : the ideas below are only mine and any way not those of the 2010 LSM organization team.

Prelude

Well, let‚Äôs speak about something that has been quite important for me this year : setting up a cross technical topics track in english.

During the 2009 LSM, I have set up with my security topic co-chairmen an English spoken afternoon with the english speakers. The French speakers that have also their talks during this afternoon have to do them in English too.

After that I have a quite long discussion with Thomas Petazzoni on internalization of talks and of the event : for Thomas,a solution combining efficiently French and English for talks does not exist. Either LSM is a total French speaking event or LSM will become a full English spoken talks event. For me, combining the two languages is a crucial point. Let‚Äôs see why (from my point of view only of course ‚Ä¶).

Why combining English and French talks is important?

To understand why combining the two languages in talks is important, it is necessary to understand my vision of the utility of events like LSM.

LSM for me (tends to) address several problems :

  • setting up bridges between free software developers from different communities (embedded vs Internet vs OS vs development etc) and languages
  • brings free software expertise from whatever it comes to LSM visitors
  • installs less barriers as possible between expertise and visitors

For me, to meet these expectations we have to be able to :

  • invite non french spoken speakers (expertise, bridge)
  • combine their talks with french talks (bridge, less barriers)

The 2010 answer at a Program level

So we invite english spoken speakers.

And in counterpart, to put them in a situation the more comfortable we can, we decide this year to set up a cross technical topics continuous english spoken track. Our goal was to be able to say to english spearkers that at any hour of any day of LSM, they were able to find a technical talk in english.

And this is exactly what we manage to set up through the commitment and hard work of all topic chairmen and speakers.

The result is here :

  • English program details
  • English tracks schedule

Why we do not succeed to provide a comfortable event for English speakers ?

First of all, because if you want to do so, it is definitively not at the Program level you have to work. It is at the top level of the event organization.

Through several long and deep discussions with Uriel, Jamey and Sarah Sharp, and Thomas several points emerge :

  • inconsistent signalization and translations
  • English track for talks has not been actively promoted enough on the website
  • a single point of contact for foreign speakers has always to be set up because coming from Oslo or Sydney and only speaking English is far not as simple as coming from Paris and speaking French
  • a single location is a definitive requirement to make talks, people, events easily accessed for English spoken people

And I mention only a subset of all the remarks they made.

Ways to improve the process

First, we have to address above problems.

But if I have to select one proposal, it would be the proposal made by Jamey which would be a major step IMHO on the road on a successful internationalized event : having a non French speaking person in the core team of the organization to be the ‚ÄúInternational conscience‚Äù of the event. This person would check all materials produced by the organization (website, practical informations, locations, process etc) from an International point of view.

Jamey said also it would be necessary to made an international call for paper. I agree despite the fact it requires some solids networks to succeed.

And to understand why even small details can break your initiative on the road to success, I let the final word to Sarah :

‚ÄúYou want an idea to improve my LSM experience ? Just add a flag on the badge of each person to say what language each person speaks !‚Äù

Enough said !

Conclusion

We try, we don‚Äôt (entirely) succeed, we want to improve : thank you for your presence and your already made feedbacks ! We welcome another feedbaks of course.

For my part, I strongly believe mix-language speakers and talks are requirements to improve exchanges, networks but also local (the french area where LSM takes place each year) access to Free Software expertise. But to do so, we have to improve STRONGLY the way we handle internationalization of the event and the way we receive foreign people.

item.title: Article MISC mai 2007 - Mon serveur DNS, mon IDS oubli√©
item.description:
Cet article est issu de l‚Äôarticle publi√© dans le num√©ro de MISC n¬∞31 de Mai 2007. J‚Äôen suis l‚Äôauteur (christophe.brocas@free.fr). Tous droits r√©serv√©s √† MISC.

Je le poste ici car l‚Äôid√©e d‚Äôutiliser son serveur DNS semble √™tre dans l‚Äôactualit√© du monde de la d√©tection d‚Äôintrusions.

Mon serveur DNS, mon IDS pr√©f√©r√©

Le Syst√®me d‚ÄôInformation (SI) des entreprises est un capital de ressources √† prot√©ger des attaques et, si une attaque r√©ussit, la compromission et les √©vasions de donn√©es doivent √™tre d√©tect√©es le plus t√¥t possible. Pour d√©tecter des postes compromis sur le r√©seau de l‚Äôentreprise, des solutions complexes et on√©reuses sont souvent propos√©es aux Directeurs Informatiques (DSI) mais le plus souvent, peu de solutions de d√©tection anti-intrusions sont effectivement en place. Or, la bonne compr√©hension √† la fois de son architecture et du comportement des codes malicieux pr√©sents sur les postes compromis permet de proposer une premi√®re r√©ponse √©l√©gante, peu couteuse et efficiente √† cette probl√©matique.

1. Introduction

1.1 Compromission de postes : une d√©tection, quelle d√©tection ?

Afin de s√©curiser son SI, une entreprise doit d√©ployer une interconnexion applicative filtr√©e par des proxies et des serveurs d√©di√©es (exemples : filtrage http/smtp, relais dns) afin de pouvoir fixer des r√®gles de s√©curit√© consistantes.

Cependant, une fois cette architecture d√©ploy√©e, la majorit√© des entreprises ne semble pas se pr√©occuper des tentatives de contournement/d‚Äôacc√®s direct √† l‚Äôext√©rieur depuis un poste du LAN compromis. Elles se reposent g√©n√©ralement sur les diff√©rentes alertes que peuvent remonter les solutions d‚Äôantivirus postes et serveurs.

Or, si les protections amont de filtrages des flux HTTP/SMTP sont utiles, la d√©tection des postes compromis est n√©cessaire tant sur le plan de l‚Äôint√©grit√© des donn√©es de son SI que sur le plan de la responsabilit√© de l‚Äôentreprise qui pourrait ainsi fournir, par exemple, une base √† des r√©seaux de postes zombies.

1.2 Avoir un IDS sans le savoir

La solution ? L‚Äôanalyse des serveurs applicatifs est un moyen simple de conna√Ætre les compromissions potentielles dans son LAN. Les logs du serveur DNS et, dans une moindre mesure, ceux du pare-feu sont des sources de donn√©es disponibles pour effectuer cette veille anti-intrusion.

Concentrons-nous sur le DNS : comment diable un serveur DNS peut-il nous r√©v√©ler les intrusions d√©j√† effectu√©es sur son r√©seau ? Et les r√©ponses sont :

  • comprendre le comportement des diff√©rents types de codes malicieux pr√©sents sur les postes compromis ;
  • en d√©duire les types de requ√™tes DNS pouvant √™tre √©mis par ces codes ;
  • en fonction de ces profils, analyser les logs du serveur DNS et isoler les postes susceptibles d‚Äô√™tre compromis.

2. Architecture √† base de proxies et de relais : un pr√©-requis n√©cessaire

Mais, attention, dans les logs d‚Äôun serveur DNS, rien ne distingue une requ√™te √©mise par un poste de celle √©mise par un autre. Le seul moyen de stigmatiser une requ√™te √©mise par un poste en particulier est de pouvoir d√©finir le comportement normal d‚Äôun poste en termes de requ√™tes DNS. Et ce, par rapport √† celui, diff√©rent, des serveurs de type proxies ou relais.

2.1 Flux vers l‚ÄôInternet : ‚Äúauthentication required‚Äù !

Les flux √©mis vers l‚ÄôInternet depuis un poste de travail sont nombreux :

  • √©mis consciemment par l‚Äôutilisateur : envoi d‚Äôemail, navigation sur le web ou t√©l√©chargement de fichiers etc ;
  • mais aussi √©mis de mani√®re invisible pour l‚Äôutilisateur : mise √† jour du syst√®me d‚Äôexploitation, rapatriement de mises √† jour antivirales etc .

Et je ne parle que des flux l√©gitimes !

Figure 1 : architecture proxies et serveurs relais

Et pour √™tre reconnus comme l√©gitimes, l‚Äôensemble de ces flux doivent √™tre soumis √† habilitation. Pour cela, il faut que ces flux soient rerout√©s de mani√®re syst√©matique vers des √©quipements de filtrage n√©cessitant une habilitation, √† savoir les proxies ou serveur relais. 2.2 Proxies et relais, uniques √©metteurs de requ√™tes DNS vers Internet

Les machines proxies ou relais se doivent, pour √™tre utilis√©es, d‚Äôexiger de l‚Äôutilisateur une authentification. Les flux √©mis par les postes vers Internet sont alors authentifi√©s, donc moins sujet √† √™tre vecteur d‚Äôattaques.

Figure 2 : √©tapes d‚Äôune requ√™te HTTP

Le gain de cette architecture en termes de d√©tection d‚Äôintrusion ? Tout le trafic √©mis par les postes √† destination de l‚ÄôInternet est dans un premier temps redirig√© vers ces machines interm√©diaires. Les requ√™tes DNS de r√©solution de domaines internet ne sont alors plus √©mises que par ces √©quipements proxies et relais :

  • En effet, afin de pouvoir router, par exemple, les requ√™tes HTTP vers google.fr √©mises par un poste (point 1 sur la figure 2) ;
  • Le proxy de l‚Äôentreprise demande une r√©solution DNS de type A sur le domaine google.fr (point 2) pour le compte de ce poste ;
  • La requ√™te peut ensuite √™tre √©mise vers le serveur HTTP cible (point 3).

NB : Il en est de m√™me pour les envois de mails o√π le serveur SMTP joue le r√¥le du proxy HTTP.

Comme vous pouvez le voir, gr√¢ce √† cette architecture centralis√©e et ma√Ætris√©e, les logs de votre serveur DNS deviennent de mani√®re m√©canique des sources fiables de donn√©es de d√©tection d‚Äôintrusion : toute demande de r√©solution DNS d‚Äôun domaine internet √©mise par un poste lambda peut √™tre consid√©r√©e comme une alerte d‚Äôune compromission potentielle.

3. Configuration du serveur DNS Bind

3.1 Configuration par d√©faut : √©tat des lieux

Les configurations figurant dans cet article d√©crivent la configuration d‚Äôun serveur DNS Bind et ont √©t√© test√©es avec un serveur Bind en version stable 9.3.2 sous Ubuntu 6.06.

La configuration par d√©faut d‚Äôun serveur DNS Bind ne collecte pas dans ses fichiers de logs les requ√™tes √©mises par les clients DNS. En effet, ces requ√™tes peuvent g√©n√©rer beaucoup d‚Äô√©critures dans ces fichiers dont la taille peut donc augmenter rapidement. Nous allons donc utiliser la gestion automatique des fichiers de logs fournie par Bind, gestion am√©lior√©e depuis la version 9.3 par la gestion d‚Äôune taille maximale de fichiers de logs. Une pr√©sentation des options de logging de Bind a √©t√© faite dans un article pr√©c√©dent de MISC.

3.2 Collecte des requ√™tes clientes dans les logs de Bind

Voici un exemple de d√©finition d‚Äôun channel permettant de collecter les requ√™tes √©mises par les clients :

# Declenchement du log des requetes au demarrage de Bind
querylog;

# paragraphe definissant le logging
logging {
   // Parametrage du canal des requetes
   channel querieslogs {
       // Envoi vers le fichier queries.log avec roulement de 10 archives de 20Mo
              file "queries.log" versions 10 size 20m;
       // Affiche la date du message dans les logs
              print-time yes;
       // Affiche le nom de la categorie du message
              print-category yes;
   };

   // Envoi des requetes dans notre canal querieslogs

};

Des fichiers de configuration complets pour chaque type de serveur (cache interne, cache internet, maitre interne et maitre internet avec des sections de logs compl√®tes sont disponibles sur le site de MISC. De plus, vous trouverez la documentation exhaustive des options de log de Bind en ligne sur le site du logiciel.

4. Que chercher dans les logs ?

4.1 Topologie du comportement r√©seaux des codes malicieux

Un poste de travail compromis par un code malicieux a pour vocation de devenir une source d‚Äôinformations √©mises √† destination de serveurs externes, ou une source d‚Äôattaques pouvant √™tre pil√¥t√©es ou pas depuis Internet. Dans les deux cas, une communication vers des serveurs externes tentera d‚Äô√™tre initi√©e. Ces serveurs peuvent √™tre des cibles d‚Äôattaques (spams, d√©nis de services distribu√©es), des serveurs de contr√¥le fournissant des instructions aux codes malicieux distribu√©es ou bien des serveurs de collecte d‚Äôinformations usurp√©es √† l‚Äôutilisateur du poste.

4.2 Requ√™tes DNS √©mises par des codes malicieux

Ils existent deux grands types de requ√™tes :

  • les requ√™tes de type MX qui sont √©mises par les moteurs d‚Äôenvoi de spams et de virus qui sont lanc√©s sur les postes une fois compromis. De m√™me, ces requ√™tes servent √† ces codes malicieux pour se propager via email. Ce type de requ√™te fournit le nom et l‚Äôadresse IP du(des) serveur(s) SMTP r√©ceptionnant pour le domaine pass√© en param√®tre ;
  • les requ√™tes de type A repr√©sentent la majeure partie des requ√™tes restantes. Ces requ√™tes peuvent alors correspondre √† des demandes de r√©solution de noms de futures cibles, de serveurs de t√©l√©chargement de nouveaux codes malicieux (ou de mises √† jour) ou encore de sites fournissant des ordres aux codes malicieux(serveurs IRC par exemple) .

Pour les requ√™tes MX, on peut en avoir la trace pas plus loin que dans sa messagerie. Exemple d‚Äôent√™te de spam dans la BAL de votre serviteur :

Nous avons d√©crit dans le chapitre 2 un pr√©-requis ambitieux qui √©tait que toutes les communications ou tentatives de communication vers Internet √©mises par les postes de travail passaient par un proxy ou une machine relais. Or, la premi√®re analyse que vous allez mener sur les donn√©es extraites des logs de votre serveur DNS risque fort de plus vous mettre sur la trace de postes lan√ßant des Windows Update que sur celle de postes zombies (du moins je l‚Äôesp√®re pour votre LAN‚Äâ;-) ).

6. Limites et pistes d‚Äôam√©liorations

L‚Äôexploitabilit√© de cette solution serait de travailler sur l‚Äôenchainement des op√©rations de recherche dans les fichiers de logs, cyclage, compression et suppression de ces fichiers.

Pour ce qui est de la consolidation, il faudrait d√©clencher de telles recherches sur les rejets du Firewall concernant des requ√™tes en provenance de postes en plan d‚Äôadressage interne (ex: 10.0.0.0/8) √† destination d‚Äôadresses externes (vers l‚Äôinternet donc).

7. Conclusion

Comme nous venons de le voir, une architecture qui permet de bien ma√Ætriser les flux de donn√©es coupl√©e √† une analyse des logs de son (ses) serveur(s) DNS permet de disposer d‚Äôune sonde de d√©tection de postes compromis. Cette solution a l‚Äôavantage d‚Äô√™tre l√©g√®re, non structurante et ‚Ä¶ ne co√ªte rien ! Cela n‚Äôemp√™che en aucun cas le RSSI ou le DSI de doter l‚Äôentreprise de solutions plus compl√®te (et complexe), intrusive et ch√®re.

2. Architecture

Pour maitriser au mieux le DNS et son utilisation, nous fixons les r√®gles suivantes :

  • Aucune machine du r√©seau interne ne peut acc√®der √† l‚Äôinternet. Elles utilisent toutes un proxy HTTP pour le web ou un relais SMTP pour la messagerie;
  • Aucune machine ne peut donc r√©soudre autre chose que le domaine mondomaine.fr. Cela permet d‚Äô√™tre s√ªr de pouvoir d√©ployer une politique de s√©curit√© maitrisable.

2.1 Les serveurs DNS et leur r√¥le

La base pour fixer une politique de r√©solution est donc de d√©finir un p√©rim√®tre et des r√®gles d‚Äôacc√®s :

2.2 R√©solution d‚Äôune requ√™te interne du domaine ou d‚Äôun sous-domaine de l‚Äôentreprise

3. Serveur DNS cache interne

3.1 Attention au poste de travail‚Äâ!

Comme nous le disions en introduction, la corruption de donn√©es de r√©solution est le probl√®me majeur du DNS.

Et bien, la premi√®re attaque DNS est d‚Äô√©viter toute requ√™te DNS‚Äâ! En effet, la r√©solution de noms dans les syst√®mes d‚Äôexploitation modernes impliquent des composants autres que les serveurs DNS.

3.2 Configuration du serveur DNS cache interne

Une fois que le poste client nous semble correctement configur√©, voyons la configuration du serveur de cache interne. Dans notre exemple, les machines du r√©seau interne sont dans le r√©seau 10.1.0.0/16 et le serveur cache interne a l‚Äôadresse 10.1.255.4.

Cette mesure combin√©e √† la fermeture de tous les ports r√©seaux (comme HTTP/S ou SMTP) pour les machines du LAN au niveau du firewall emp√™che toute capacit√© d‚Äô√©vasion par tunnel DNS autonome. Pour que l‚Äô√©vasion soit d√©sormais possible, il faut que l‚Äôattaquant dispose du code d‚Äôauthentification de l‚Äôutilisateur sur le proxy applicatif ce qui limite grandement la menace des attaques automatis√©es. Et nous sortons l√† du p√©rim√®tre de la s√©curisation du DNS.

4.1 Mise en s√ªret√© des informations

Les informations contenues dans le DNS SOA interne font de ce DNS le coeur de notre syst√®me. En effet, il est le seul √† contenir les donn√©es de r√©solution et doit √† ce titre √™tre le plus prot√©g√©. Ce DNS est plac√© derri√®re un pare-feu voire un IPS impl√©mentant un contr√¥le d‚Äô√©tat sur UDP performant. Ces restrictions limitent les risques de d√©ni de services sur notre DNS SOA interne, le nombre de clients simultan√©s √©tant limit√© par le nombre de DNS cache.

4.2 Les mises √† jour dynamiques

Certaines applications de l‚Äôentreprise peuvent n√©cessiter la mise en place des mises √† jour dynamiques (serveur DHCP, contr√¥leur de domaine, etc.) sur notre DNS SOA. Dans ce cas, il est int√©ressant de cr√©er des sous-domaines particuliers pour ces applications, celles-ci ne peuvent alors pas tout modifier dans notre DNS.

Par exemple, on peut cr√©er le sous-domaine dhcp.mondomaine.fr sur notre DNS et autoriser le serveur DHCP √† y effectuer ses mises √† jour sans lui donner de droits sur mondomaine.fr.
